http://www.cnn.com/2005/TECH/space/07/13/space.shuttle/index.html
 
 Thanks for pushing the boundries of human knowledge and achievement!

post_info.post_title: Best of luck to Astronauts and everyone at NASA!

Just got to keep at it. Although I'm sure my mom is ****** at having to stay in down in Florida another day with the rest of the materials team.

http://www.cnn.com/2005/TECH/space/07/13/space.shuttle/index.html
 
 Thanks for pushing the boundries of human knowledge and achievement!
 
 

 
 Thanks for the sentiment, but I'm not sure how much we're pushing boundaries. These space shuttles are glorified delivery trucks, IMO, doing mundane chores and not going anywhere but up and down. 
 
 We need to go somewhere.

Well, one of the eventual, though far off goals of the ISS is to test the abilitity to be able to build a ship in space, one that could be interstellar. Whether or not that will work remains to be seen, but we won't know unless we try. They may not be literally pushing spatial boundaries, but they're pushing scientific ones.

I won't wish them luck, because if thats what they are relying on they are as good as dead already.
 
 I think I'll wish NASA influence in high places so their next orbiter is not the "bargain basement" option they got in the Space Shuttle, whose two accidents have resulted from issues around the solid rocket booster stage.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Best of luck to Astronauts and everyone at NASA!
